nodes.text: Use this document as an overview tool for assent/informed consent forms in pediatric clinical trials
Apply this guidance to pediatric clinical trials with medicinal products in Europe
Include patients aged from birth to less than 18 years in the scope of this guidance
Use the term 'child(ren)' to mean minors as defined in the Clinical Trials Regulation
Define 'minor' as a subject under the age of legal competence to give informed consent
Consider that the age of legal competence differs across national laws
Use the term 'paediatric population' to refer to children aged from birth to less than 18 years
Categorize paediatric participants into age groups: newborns/infants, pre-schoolers, schoolers, and adolescents
Obtain assent from minors capable of forming an opinion, in addition to consent from legal representatives
Comply with national laws regarding minor assent in clinical trials
Treat assent as a statement of will with legal value according to national law
Implement blinding/masking procedures in clinical trials when appropriate
Use Case Report Forms (CRFs) to collect clinical trial data
Ensure compliance with all applicable regulations for clinical trials
Investigators should request agreement from minors for trial participation
Minor's agreement is not sufficient without parental/representative consent
CTAs must provide comprehensive information about investigational medicinal products
CTAs must provide comprehensive information about planned trials
EMA will set up and maintain the Clinical Trials Information System
CTIS will contain centralized EU portal for CTA submission and assessment
Follow Good Clinical Practice (GCP) guidelines
Establish an Independent Data-Monitoring Committee (IDMC)
The Clinical Trials Regulation must harmonize assessment and supervision of clinical trials in the EU
Investigators must respect a capable minor's explicit wish to refuse or withdraw from a clinical trial
Dissent means the minor's expression to refuse participation in a trial
Lack of assent from a minor is equivalent to refusal to participate, when national law requires minor assent
A minor may express dissent verbally or through other means
An Investigator's Brochure must be provided
A legally acceptable representative may provide consent for participants unable to do so
Dissent should be respected in clinical trials
Informed consent must include all aspects relevant to the subject's decision to participate
For minors and incapacitated subjects, consent must be obtained from their legally designated representative
A legal representative must be empowered by Member State law to give informed consent
For most minors, the legally designated representative will be one or both parents
Original medical records must be maintained
A protocol must be established for clinical trials
Protocol amendments should be documented
Both parents should be encouraged to participate in the informed consent process
Orphans should not be excluded from clinical trials
Children whose parents no longer have parental authority should not be excluded from clinical trials
Informed consent must be requested from the legally designated representative for orphans
Parents/legally designated representatives must protect their child in the consent process
Parents/legally designated representatives should consider the child's point of view in the consent process
Define sponsor-investigator
Define standard operating procedures (SOPs)
Informed consent must be obtained from prospective trial participants
Participants must be informed of all main aspects of the trial
Potential risks, inconveniences and costs must be disclosed to participants
Informed consent must be documented in writing
Informed consent forms must be signed and dated
Informed consent may be documented in paper or electronic format
Obtain informed consent from child's parent(s)/legal representative(s) for trial participation
Adapt information to child's age, maturity, medical condition, and circumstances
Arrange translation of information where appropriate
Verify legal representative(s) understood the provided information
Verify child's/adolescent's opinions as their understanding evolves
Present full trial information to legal representative(s) orally and in writing
Maintain trial records and reports
Submit safety reports
Communication should be based on trust and equality between all parties
Communication should respect the autonomy of the child/adolescent
Communication should be transparent with information given
Sensitive adolescent information must be managed confidentially by healthcare professionals
Participants must be informed that personal data will be pseudoanonymised
Participants must be informed where and how personal data will be stored
Participants must be informed who will have access to their personal data
Distinguish between CTR informed consent and GDPR consent for data processing
Treat informed consent as a safeguard, not a legal basis for data processing
Create a publicly available informed consent and assent overview tool
Design consent/assent documentation case-by-case for each clinical trial
Consider age-specific elements when designing pediatric consent/assent documents
Adapt consent guidance to local requirements for pediatric clinical trials
Noncompliance in clinical trials must be addressed
Clinical trial reports must be prepared
Use the guidance document to prepare paediatric clinical trial submissions in the EU
Include children in the consent/assent processes for clinical trials
Raise awareness about children's rights to express opinions on trial participation
Use EU legislative and regulatory texts on paediatrics as primary data source
Collect informed consent, assent or agreement documents for paediatric trials
Consider requirements for four paediatric age groups: 0-2, 2-5, 6-9, 10-18
Include methods for assessing efficacy in the protocol
Describe safety assessment procedures in the protocol
eYPAGnet members should identify issues or missing details in the first document version
eYPAGnet members should provide supportive real-life comments on implementation
Real-life comments must be incorporated as questions or example methods in the guidance
The WG must design three-level recommendations using traffic light symbols
Recommendations should be created for all four age groups
A cross symbol indicates an element does not need to be included for an age group
Check national regulatory requirements when preparing consent/assent documents
Use this document only as guidance together with local/national requirements
Refer to national legislation for informed consent requirements in each EU/EEA country
Consult Toolkit table for country-specific informed consent/assent requirements
Update document with new legislative/regulatory information via Enpr-EMA secretariat
The guideline may be applied to other clinical investigations impacting human subjects
The EU CTR will harmonize the CTA process across Member States
A fully functional CTIS must be developed before CTR application
Content for patient information and consent documents must follow current EU legislation
Detailed informed consent requirements remain within remit of each Member State
Practical examples should be provided by Enpr-EMA Ethics Working Group members
eYPAGnet members should provide feedback on critical consent process questions
Include Table 1 with general information for informed consent and assent
Include Table 2 with trial-specific information for informed consent and assent
Use asterisk to denote legal representative(s)/parent(s) in tables
Define legal representative as person empowered to act for another
Use 3-level recommendation symbols for all age groups
Include references on page 18
Documentation must allow reconstruction of the course of events
Blinding procedures should be used to keep parties unaware of treatment assignments
Language in consent documents must be concise, clear, relevant and understandable
Language in consent documents must be adapted to the age and maturity of the recipient
Assent/informed consent should be documented
Reasons for not seeking child assent must be explained if not possible
Personnel providing consent information should be competent in communicating with children and families
Ensure children are properly informed during consent process
Provide time and space for discussion and decision during consent process
Use correct grammar in assent/consent documents
Use age-appropriate form of address for children/adolescents
Use visual and informative materials to increase understanding
Limit assent/consent document to maximum 3 pages or 3 screen views
Use large enough font in assent/consent documents
Use clear layout in assent/consent documents
Use different colors to highlight important information
Explain the concept of a clinical trial in the assent/consent document
Explain how the clinical trial differs from normal routine care
Explain relevant trial methodology (e.g. randomization) in a short, simple way
Respect the child/adolescent's explicit wish regarding trial participation
Ensure child/adolescent understands they may refuse or withdraw at any time
Provide age-appropriate information to children, including visual aids if appropriate
Resistance of very young children should be identified
Resistance of very young children should be discussed with legal representatives
Older adolescents must have an opportunity for private conversation about confidential issues
An independent person or method should be available for adolescents to express concerns
Re-assent should be obtained as the child matures in long-term studies
Check if assent or consent is legally required for the child
Subjects must voluntarily confirm willingness to participate after being informed of trial aspects
Adapt informed consent procedure to child's age and mental maturity
Children capable of forming an opinion should provide assent to participate
Child assent may be provided in written form
Child assent must comply with national requirements
Parents may explain trial to younger children using 'story telling' method
Include EUCTR number and trial protocol code in consent documents
Register trial in EudraCT before starting
Explain what data is needed and why for the trial
Use a glossary of definitions for complex protocols
Explain why the child/adolescent was invited to participate
Provide information about all personnel involved in conducting the trial
Describe the professional expertise of trial personnel
Introduce the investigational product(s)/placebo/device used in the trial
Clinical trials must pose only minimal risk and burden for child/adolescent participants compared to standard care
Explain the scientific rationale for using placebo if used in the trial
Describe existing alternative treatments if the child/adolescent does not participate in the trial
Explain the risks of premature termination to legal representatives and children with capacity to understand
Reassure that withdrawal will not affect normal treatment availability
Explain possible benefits of trial participation for the child/adolescent
Describe procedures, tests, and measurements according to the trial protocol
Blood volumes and sample methods should follow guideline recommendations
Non-invasive procedures should be preferred where possible
Legal representatives and children must be informed if a procedure is standard care or trial-specific
An explanation about procedures must be offered to legal representatives and children in honest language
The expected duration of participation must be stated
Use flow-charts to explain trial visits and schedule
Source data must include all information necessary to reconstruct and evaluate the trial
Source documents must be original records or certified copies
Risk and burden assessments must be conducted prior to the trial
Anticipated risks and burdens must be described during the assent/consent process
Follow national requirements for genetic testing
A separate consent/assent may be required for genetic tests
Disclosure of genetic information to minors requires precautions or expert counselling
Explain the scientific rationale for genetic testing if planned in a trial
Subinvestigators must be designated and supervised by the investigator
Discuss biobank samples, retention and consent for future data processing in the protocol
Follow national requirements and legislation for biological samples
Specify the types of biological samples being collected
Explain the purpose for collecting biological samples
Describe the method for collecting biological samples
Specify where and for how long biological samples will be stored
Discuss potential teratogenic risks during pregnancy/fertility for both females and males
Explain the possibility and type of contraception to be used if required
Explain procedures to follow if pregnancy occurs during the trial
Obtain consent when child reaches age of legal competence to continue in trial
Define emergency situations and conditions for deferred consent in protocol
Provide full explanation after emergency situations with deferred consent
Clearly state what data from patient files is needed and why
Clearly state how collected patient data will be used
Clearly state who has access to patient data, using names if required
Explain how patient data anonymisation is performed
Store patient data anonymously
Explain procedures for adverse reaction documentation and reporting during trials
Explain options for further care/medication after trial discontinuation
Implement quality assurance procedures for every aspect of the trial
Assent/consent must explain probability and magnitude of harm anticipated in the trial
Assent/consent must explain how risks will be minimized, followed and handled
Stopping rules must be included in the trial protocol
Children/adolescents should not pay for IMPs or auxiliary products used in the trial
All compensation should be according to national requirements
No financial inducements should be offered, except compensation for expenses and lost earnings
Small tokens of appreciation must be approved by the Ethics Committee
Information about applicable damage compensation must be included in consent documents
Compensation should be assured for damages
Member States must ensure a system for damage compensation is in place
Sponsors are responsible for ensuring appropriate damage compensation
Insurance should not waive liabilities for long-term effects in children
Information about availability of trial results must be stated in consent documents
Trial information must be understandable to a layperson
Trial information must be available through EU database (portal)
Information about Competent Authority authorizations must be provided
Information about Ethics Committee review/approvals must be provided
Reviewers must be independent of the sponsor, investigator and trial
Information about who has reviewed/approved the trial must be provided
Information about the sponsor/funding of the trial must be provided
It should be stated that the hospital receives money, not the investigator directly
Clearly differentiate between the investigator and sponsor interests
Provide contact information for who can be contacted during the trial
Give contact information to all trial participants
Verify that legal representatives and children understand the trial information
Provide answers to all questions asked by children/adolescents and legal representatives
Resolve any unclear issues during the consent/assent discussion
Consider using an additional summary leaflet for complex trials
No subject should be admitted to a trial before IRB/IEC written approval
Clinical trials on medicinal products for human use must comply with Regulation EU No 536/2014
Medicinal products for pediatric use must comply with Regulation (EC) No 1901/2006
Clinical trials must implement good clinical practice as per Directive 2001/20/EC
Member States must align laws and regulations with EU clinical trial directives
Sponsors should consult EudraLex Volume 10 for clinical trial regulations
Investigators should be qualified by education, training, and experience to conduct the trial
Investigators should meet all qualifications specified by applicable regulatory requirements
Investigators should provide evidence of qualifications through up-to-date CV and other relevant documentation
Comply with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) for processing personal data
Follow informed consent requirements for pediatric clinical trials in Europe
Adhere to the Clinical Trials Regulation in conjunction with GDPR
Consult the EMA toolkit on informed consent for pediatric clinical trials
Refer to the European Commission Q&A on interplay between Clinical Trials Regulation and GDPR
Investigator should demonstrate potential for recruiting required number of suitable subjects within agreed period
Investigator should have sufficient time to properly conduct and complete the trial within agreed period
Investigator should have adequate qualified staff and facilities for trial duration to conduct trial properly and safely
Develop a strategy for paediatric clinical trials
Identify unmet therapeutic needs in children
Improve communication between stakeholders in paediatric research
Facilitate the implementation of new EU regulations on clinical trials
Involve young people and families in paediatric clinical research
Investigators must obtain IRB/IEC approval before initiating a trial
Provide IRB/IEC with current copy of Investigator's Brochure
Supply updated Investigator's Brochure to IRB/IEC if updated during trial
Provide all review documents to IRB/IEC during the trial
Conduct trial in compliance with agreed protocol
Investigator/institution and sponsor should sign the protocol or alternative contract
Do not deviate from protocol without sponsor agreement and IRB/IEC approval
Protocol deviations allowed to eliminate immediate hazards to subjects
Investigator should document any deviation from the approved protocol
Investigator should explain any deviation from the approved protocol
Investigator may implement protocol deviations to eliminate immediate hazards without prior approval
Implemented deviations must be submitted to IRB/IEC for review and approval
Implemented deviations must be submitted to sponsor for agreement
Investigator is responsible for investigational product accountability at trial sites
Investigator may assign product accountability duties to an appropriate pharmacist or individual
Records of product delivery, inventory, use, and return must be maintained
Investigators should maintain records documenting subjects received protocol-specified doses
Investigators should reconcile all investigational product received from the sponsor
Investigational products should be stored as specified by the sponsor
Investigational products should be stored in accordance with applicable regulatory requirements
Investigator should ensure investigational products are used only in accordance with approved protocol
Investigator or designee should explain correct use of investigational product to each subject
Investigator should check at appropriate intervals that subjects are following instructions properly
Investigator should follow the trial's randomization procedures
Investigator should comply with applicable regulatory requirements for informed consent
Investigator should adhere to GCP and ethical principles from Declaration of Helsinki
Obtain IRB/IEC written approval of informed consent form before trial begins
Revise informed consent form when important new information becomes available
Obtain IRB/IEC approval for revised informed consent forms before use
Inform subjects of new information relevant to continued participation
Do not coerce or unduly influence subjects to participate or continue in trial
Informed consent must not waive legal rights or release parties from liability for negligence
Investigator should fully inform subject or representative of all trial aspects
Trial information should be in non-technical, understandable language
Investigator should provide ample time for subject to inquire about trial details
All subject questions about the trial should be answered satisfactorily
Written informed consent form must be signed prior to subject's trial participation
Informed consent forms must be signed and dated by the subject or their representative
Informed consent forms must be signed and dated by the person conducting the consent discussion
An impartial witness should be present for consent discussions if subject/representative cannot read
The witness must sign and date the consent form after oral consent is given
Consent forms must explain that the trial involves research
Consent forms must explain the purpose of the trial
Inform subjects of trial treatment(s) and probability of random assignment
Describe all trial procedures, including invasive procedures, to subjects
Explain subject responsibilities to participants
Identify experimental aspects of the trial to subjects
Disclose foreseeable risks and inconveniences to subjects
Explain expected benefits or lack thereof to subjects
Describe alternative treatments and their potential benefits/risks
Subject records must be kept confidential
Subject identity must remain confidential if trial results are published
Inform subjects of new information relevant to continued participation
Provide contact information for trial inquiries and injury reporting
Disclose circumstances under which subject participation may be terminated
Inform subjects of expected trial duration
Disclose approximate number of trial subjects
Provide subjects with a copy of signed informed consent form
Provide subjects a copy of their signed and dated consent form
Give subjects copies of any amendments to written trial information
Inform subjects with limited capacity about the trial to the extent of their understanding
Have capable subjects with limited capacity sign and date the informed consent form
Obtain personal consent from subjects in non-therapeutic trials
Seek IRB/IEC approval for including subjects with consent by legal representative
Trials should be conducted in patients with the condition the product is intended for
Subjects in trials should be closely monitored
Withdraw subjects who appear unduly distressed
In emergencies, get consent from subject's legal representative if available
Emergency enrollment without consent requires IRB/IEC approved measures
Inform emergency enrolled subjects about the trial as soon as possible
Investigators must ensure accuracy and completeness of data reported to sponsor
CRF data must be consistent with source documents
Changes or corrections to CRFs should be dated, initialed, and explained if necessary
Changes to CRFs should not obscure the original entry
Sponsors should provide guidance on making corrections to CRFs
Sponsors must have written procedures for CRF changes made by their representatives
Investigators should retain records of CRF changes and corrections
Investigators must maintain trial documents as specified in Essential Documents
Investigators should prevent accidental or premature destruction of trial documents
Essential documents should be retained for at least 2 years after last marketing approval
Retain documents for longer if required by regulations or sponsor agreement
Sponsor must inform investigator when documents no longer need to be retained
Document financial aspects of trial in sponsor-investigator agreement
Make trial records available upon request to monitor, auditor, IRB/IEC, or regulatory authority
Submit written trial status summaries to IRB/IEC annually or as requested
Promptly report significant trial changes or increased subject risks
Report all serious adverse events immediately to sponsor
Identify subjects by unique code numbers in adverse event reports
Investigator should comply with regulatory requirements for reporting unexpected serious adverse drug reactions
Report critical safety events to sponsor within timeframes specified in protocol
Provide sponsor and IRB/IEC with additional requested information for reported deaths
Promptly inform trial subjects if trial is prematurely terminated or suspended
Ensure appropriate therapy and follow-up for subjects if trial is terminated
Inform regulatory authorities if trial is terminated, where required by regulations
Investigator must inform institution if terminating trial without sponsor agreement
Provide sponsor and IRB/IEC detailed written explanation for trial termination
Investigator should inform the institution if sponsor terminates/suspends a trial
Investigator/institution should inform IRB/IEC if sponsor terminates/suspends a trial
Investigator/institution should provide IRB/IEC written explanation of trial termination/suspension
Investigator should inform institution if IRB/IEC terminates/suspends trial approval
Investigator/institution should notify sponsor if IRB/IEC terminates/suspends trial approval
Investigator/institution should provide sponsor written explanation of IRB/IEC approval termination
Investigator should inform institution upon trial completion
Investigator/institution should provide IRB/IEC with trial outcome summary upon completion
Quality control should be applied to each stage of data handling
Agreements with investigators and other parties should be in writing
A sponsor may transfer trial-related duties to a CRO
The sponsor retains ultimate responsibility for trial data quality and integrity
CROs should implement quality assurance and quality control
Transferred trial duties should be specified in writing
The sponsor should designate qualified medical personnel for trial-related advice
Sponsor should utilize qualified individuals throughout all stages of the trial process
Sponsor should utilize appropriately qualified individuals to supervise overall trial conduct
Sponsor should utilize qualified individuals to handle and verify trial data
Sponsor should utilize qualified individuals to conduct statistical analyses
Sponsor may establish an independent data-monitoring committee (IDMC)
IDMC should have written operating procedures
IDMC should maintain written records of all meetings
Sponsor should ensure electronic data processing systems conform to requirements
Maintain SOPs for using electronic data systems
Ensure data changes are documented without deletion of entered data
Maintain a security system that prevents unauthorized data access
Maintain a list of individuals authorized to make data changes
Maintain adequate backup of data
Safeguard blinding during data entry and processing
Use an unambiguous subject identification code for each subject
Retain all sponsor-specific essential documents pertaining to the trial
Maintain sponsor-specific essential documents for 2+ years after discontinuing clinical development
Notify all trial investigators/institutions if discontinuing clinical development
Notify all regulatory authorities if discontinuing clinical development
Report any transfer of data ownership to appropriate authorities
Retain sponsor documents for 2+ years after last marketing approval in ICH region
Inform investigators/institutions in writing of record retention needs
Notify investigators/institutions in writing when trial records are no longer needed
Sponsor should select qualified investigators with adequate resources to conduct the trial
Sponsor is responsible for organizing coordinating committee for multicentre trials
Sponsor should provide protocol and up-to-date Investigator's Brochure to investigator before agreement
Sponsor should allow sufficient time for investigator to review protocol and information
Investigator must agree to conduct trial in compliance with GCP and regulatory requirements
Investigator must agree to comply with data recording and reporting procedures
Investigator must permit monitoring, auditing and inspection of trial
Investigator must retain essential trial documents until notified by sponsor
Sponsor should define all trial-related duties and functions prior to initiating a trial
Sponsor should establish all trial-related duties and functions prior to initiating a trial
Sponsor should allocate all trial-related duties and functions prior to initiating a trial
Sponsor should provide insurance for investigator/institution against trial-related claims if required
Sponsor policies should address costs of treatment for trial-related injuries
Compensation method for trial subjects should comply with applicable regulations
Financial aspects of trial should be documented in sponsor-investigator agreement
Sponsor should submit required applications to authorities before initiating clinical trials
Sponsor should obtain name and address of investigator's/institution's IRB/IEC
Sponsor should obtain statement that IRB/IEC operates according to GCP and applicable laws
Sponsor should obtain documented IRB/IEC approval/favorable opinion
Sponsor should obtain copy of protocol from investigator/institution if requested by IRB/IEC
Sponsor should obtain copy of informed consent form(s) if requested by IRB/IEC
Sponsor should obtain copy of IRB/IEC-requested modifications and approval date
Sponsor should obtain documentation of IRB/IEC reapprovals/re-evaluations
Ensure sufficient safety and efficacy data is available to support human exposure in trials
Update the Investigator's Brochure as significant new information becomes available
Ensure investigational products are manufactured in accordance with applicable GMP
Code and label investigational products to protect blinding if applicable
Ensure product labeling complies with applicable regulatory requirements
Determine acceptable storage conditions for investigational products
Inform all involved parties of storage and handling determinations
Package investigational products to prevent contamination and deterioration during transport and storage
Blinded trials must have a coding system for rapid product identification in emergencies
The coding system should not allow undetectable breaks of the blinding
Results of additional studies on formulation changes should be available before use in trials
The sponsor is responsible for supplying investigational products to investigators/institutions
Sponsors must obtain required documentation before supplying investigational products
Sponsors should provide written procedures for handling and storage of investigational products
Procedures should address receipt, handling, storage, dispensing, and retrieval of unused product
Ensure timely delivery of investigational products to investigators
Maintain records documenting shipment, receipt, disposition, return, and destruction of investigational products
Maintain a system for retrieving investigational products
Document retrieval of investigational products
Maintain a system for disposition of unused investigational products
Document disposition of unused investigational products
Take steps to ensure investigational products are stable over the period of use
Maintain sufficient quantities of investigational products to reconfirm specifications if needed
Investigators/institutions must provide direct access to source data/documents for trial-related monitoring
Investigators/institutions must provide direct access to source data/documents for audits
Investigators/institutions must provide direct access to source data/documents for IRB/IEC review
Investigators/institutions must provide direct access to source data/documents for regulatory inspection
Sponsors should verify each subject has consented in writing to direct access to their original medical records
Sponsors are responsible for ongoing safety evaluation of investigational products
Sponsors should promptly notify investigators/institutions of findings that could affect subject safety
Verify that the rights and well-being of human subjects are protected
Ensure trial data is accurate, complete, and verifiable from source documents
Verify trial conduct complies with approved protocol, GCP, and regulations
Sponsors should appoint monitors for the trial
Monitors should be appropriately trained with relevant scientific/clinical knowledge
Document monitor qualifications
Monitors should be familiar with the investigational product, protocol, and regulations
Sponsors should determine appropriate extent and nature of monitoring
Conduct investigator training and meetings to ensure proper trial conduct
Provide extensive written guidance to ensure proper trial conduct
Use statistically controlled sampling to select data for verification
Monitor should act as main communication line between sponsor and investigator
Verify investigator has adequate qualifications and resources throughout trial
Verify facilities, labs, equipment and staff are adequate throughout trial
Verify investigational product storage times and conditions are acceptable
Verify investigational product is supplied only to eligible subjects at specified doses
Verify disposition of unused investigational products complies with regulations
Verify investigator follows approved protocol and amendments
Verify written informed consent obtained before subject participation
Ensure investigator receives current Investigator's Brochure and trial supplies
Verify investigator and staff are performing specified trial functions
Verify investigator is enrolling only eligible subjects
Verify source documents and trial records are accurate, complete and up-to-date
Monitor must check accuracy and completeness of CRF entries against source documents
Protocol-required data must be accurately reported on CRFs and consistent with source documents
Dose and therapy modifications must be well documented for each trial subject
Adverse events, concomitant medications and illnesses must be reported on CRFs per protocol
Missed visits, tests, and examinations must be clearly reported as such on CRFs
All subject withdrawals and dropouts must be reported and explained on CRFs
Monitor must inform investigator of CRF entry errors, omissions, or illegibility
Monitor should determine if investigator is maintaining essential documents
Monitor must communicate protocol deviations to the investigator
Monitor should take action to prevent recurrence of detected deviations
Monitors should follow sponsor's established SOPs for monitoring
Monitor must submit written report after each trial site visit
Monitoring reports should include date, site, monitor name, and contacts
Monitoring reports should summarize findings, deviations, and actions taken
Sponsor should document review and follow-up of monitoring reports
Evaluate trial conduct and compliance with protocol, SOPs, GCP, and regulatory requirements
Appoint individuals independent of clinical trials/systems to conduct audits
Ensure auditors are qualified by training and experience to conduct audits properly
Document auditor qualifications
Conduct audits in accordance with sponsor's written procedures
Document observations and findings of auditors
Regulatory authorities should not routinely request audit reports
Sponsor should provide an audit certificate when required by law or regulation
Sponsor must take prompt action to secure compliance for noncompliance issues
Sponsor should terminate investigator/institution participation for serious/persistent noncompliance
Sponsor must notify regulatory authorities when terminating investigator participation due to noncompliance
Sponsor must promptly inform investigators/institutions of premature trial termination or suspension
Sponsor must promptly inform regulatory authorities of premature trial termination or suspension
Sponsor must ensure clinical trial reports are prepared and provided to regulatory agencies as required
Ensure clinical trial reports in marketing applications meet ICH Guideline standards
All investigators must conduct trials in strict compliance with the agreed protocol
Design CRFs to capture required data at all multicentre trial sites
Provide supplemental CRFs for investigators collecting additional data
Document responsibilities of coordinating and participating investigators before trial start
Instruct investigators on following protocol and uniform standards for assessments
Facilitate communication between investigators
Protocol title, identifying number, and date must be included
Name and address of sponsor and monitor must be provided
Name and title of person authorized to sign protocol must be included
Name, title, address and phone of sponsor's medical expert must be provided
Name and details of investigator(s) responsible for trial must be included
Details of physician responsible for trial-site medical decisions must be provided
Names and addresses of laboratories and institutions involved must be listed
Summarize known and potential risks and benefits to human subjects
Describe and justify route of administration, dosage, and treatment period
State that the trial will comply with protocol, GCP and applicable regulations
Describe the population to be studied
Include references to relevant literature and background data
Provide a detailed description of trial objectives and purpose
Specify primary and secondary endpoints to be measured
Specify the expected duration of subject participation
Describe the sequence and duration of all trial periods
Define stopping rules or discontinuation criteria for individual subjects
Define stopping rules or discontinuation criteria for parts of the trial
Define stopping rules or discontinuation criteria for the entire trial
Establish accountability procedures for investigational products
Maintain trial treatment randomization codes
Establish procedures for breaking randomization codes
Specify permitted and prohibited medications/treatments before and during the trial
Implement procedures to monitor subject compliance
Specify efficacy parameters for the trial
Define methods and timing for assessing efficacy parameters
Specify safety parameters for the trial
Define methods and timing for assessing safety parameters
Implement procedures for recording and reporting adverse events
Specify type and duration of subject follow-up after adverse events
Report any deviations from the original statistical plan in the protocol or final report
Specify the selection criteria for subjects to be included in analyses
Specify in protocol that investigators will permit trial-related monitoring
Specify in protocol that investigators will permit audits
Specify in protocol that investigators will permit IRB/IEC review
Specify in protocol that investigators will permit regulatory inspections
Provide direct access to source data/documents for monitoring and inspections
The IB must provide information on investigational products relevant to human subject studies
The IB should facilitate understanding of key protocol features
The IB must provide insight to support clinical management of study subjects
IB information should be presented in a concise, simple, objective, and balanced form
A medically qualified person should participate in editing the IB
The IB contents must be approved by the disciplines that generated the data
An extensive IB may not be necessary for marketed products with widely understood pharmacology
An IB specific to a new use should be prepared for marketed products studied for a new indication
The IB should be reviewed at least annually
The IB should be revised as necessary in compliance with sponsor's written procedures
Important new information should be communicated to investigators before inclusion in a revised IB
The sponsor must ensure an up-to-date IB is made available to investigators
Investigators must provide the up-to-date IB to responsible IRBs/IECs
For investigator-sponsored trials, the sponsor-investigator should determine if a brochure is available from the manufacturer
Sponsor-investigator should provide expanded background information in protocol if formal IB is impractical
IB title page must include sponsor's name
IB title page must include identity of each investigational product
IB title page must include release date
IB title page should include edition number
IB may include confidentiality statement for investigators/recipients
IB must contain a table of contents
IB must include a brief summary (preferably not exceeding two pages)
Provide a brief introductory statement for the investigational product
Include chemical name and generic/trade names of investigational product
State the pharmacological class and expected position of the product
Provide rationale for researching the investigational product
State anticipated indications for the investigational product
Describe the general approach for evaluating the investigational product
Provide a description of the investigational product substance
Include instructions for storage and handling of dosage forms
Provide summary of relevant nonclinical study results
Summary should address methodology used in nonclinical studies
Summary should address results of nonclinical studies
Summary should discuss relevance of findings to investigated therapeutic
Summary should discuss possible unfavorable effects in humans
Use tabular format/listings when possible to enhance clarity
Discuss most important findings from nonclinical studies
Address the relevance of animal study information to proposed human dosing
Compare animal and human dosing in terms of blood/tissue levels when possible
Include a summary of pharmacological aspects of the investigational product studied in animals
Incorporate studies assessing potential therapeutic activity in the pharmacology summary
Include studies assessing safety pharmacology in the pharmacology summary
Provide a summary of pharmacokinetics and metabolism of the investigational product in all studied animal species
Discuss findings on absorption and bioavailability of the investigational product and metabolites
Describe toxicological effects found in relevant animal studies under appropriate headings
Provide a thorough discussion of known effects of investigational products in humans
Include information on pharmacokinetics in the investigational product discussion
Include information on metabolism in the investigational product discussion
Include information on pharmacodynamics in the investigational product discussion
Provide a summary of each completed clinical trial where possible
Include information on results from any non-clinical trial use of the investigational product
Present a summary of pharmacokinetic information for the investigational product
Discuss implications of information from clinical trials in humans
Use summaries of safety and efficacy across multiple trials by indications in subgroups
Provide tabular summaries of adverse drug reactions for all clinical trials
Discuss important differences in adverse drug reaction patterns across indications or subgroups
Describe possible risks and adverse drug reactions based on prior experiences
Describe precautions or special monitoring for investigational use of the product
Identify countries where the investigational product has been marketed or approved
Summarize significant information from marketed use of the product
Provide an overall discussion of nonclinical and clinical data
Summarize information from various sources on different aspects of the investigational product(s)
Discuss published reports on related products where appropriate
Provide investigator with clear understanding of possible risks and adverse reactions
Describe specific tests, observations, and precautions needed for a clinical trial
Provide guidance on recognition and treatment of possible overdose and adverse drug reactions
Include sponsor's name on investigator's brochure title page
Include a Confidentiality Statement in the Investigator's Brochure
Include a Signature Page in the Investigator's Brochure
Include a Table of Contents in the Investigator's Brochure
Include a Summary section in the Investigator's Brochure
Include an Introduction section in the Investigator's Brochure
Include a Physical, Chemical, and Pharmaceutical Properties and Formulation section
Include a Nonclinical Studies section in the Investigator's Brochure
Include subsections on Pharmacology, Pharmacokinetics, and Toxicology in Nonclinical Studies
Essential documents must permit evaluation of trial conduct and data quality
Essential documents must demonstrate compliance with GCP standards
Essential documents must demonstrate compliance with regulatory requirements
Essential documents should be filed in a timely manner
Essential documents should be filed at investigator/institution sites
Essential documents should be filed at sponsor sites
Essential documents must be audited by sponsor's independent audit function
Essential documents must be inspected by regulatory authorities
Group essential documents into 3 sections based on trial stage
Establish trial master files at investigator/institution site
Establish trial master files at sponsor's office
Monitor must review investigator/institution and sponsor files before trial close-out
All documents should be available for regulatory authority inspection
An Investigator's Brochure should be generated before the trial starts
The protocol and amendments should be signed before the trial starts
An informed consent form should be prepared before the trial starts
Written information for subjects should be prepared before the trial starts
A financial agreement between investigator/institution and sponsor should be documented
An insurance statement should be prepared where required
Agreements between involved parties should be signed before the trial starts
Obtain dated, documented approval from IRB/IEC for the trial protocol and amendments
Obtain IRB/IEC approval for the informed consent form
Obtain IRB/IEC approval for any written information to be provided to subjects
Obtain IRB/IEC approval for subject recruitment advertisements, if used
Document that the IRB/IEC is constituted in agreement with GCP
Obtain regulatory authority authorization/approval/notification of protocol where required
Maintain curriculum vitae and qualifications of investigators and sub-investigators
Document normal values and/or ranges of tests included in the protocol
Document competence of facility to perform required tests
Document reliability of test results
Attach sample labels to investigational product containers
Provide instructions for handling investigational products and trial materials
Maintain shipping records for investigational products and trial materials
Obtain certificates of analysis for shipped investigational products
Document identity, purity, and strength of investigational products used in the trial
Document procedures for revealing blinded investigational product identity in emergencies
Maintain a master randomization list documenting the randomization method
Prepare a pre-trial monitoring report documenting site suitability
Prepare a trial initiation monitoring report documenting review of procedures with staff
Provide Investigator's Brochure updates to investigators in a timely manner
Document all revisions to protocol, CRF, informed consent, and other subject information
Document revisions of trial-related documents that take effect during the trial
Obtain dated, documented approval from IRB/IEC for protocol amendments
Obtain dated, documented approval from IRB/IEC for informed consent form revisions
Obtain dated, documented approval from IRB/IEC for subject recruitment advertisements
Identify version number and date of documents approved by IRB/IEC
Obtain regulatory authority approvals for protocol amendments where required
Maintain updated CVs for new investigators and sub-investigators
Establish quality control for tests used in the trial
Implement external quality assessment for tests where required
Document that tests remain adequate throughout the trial period
Document shipment of investigational products and trial-related materials
Obtain certificates of analysis for new batches of investigational products
Document site visits and findings by the monitor in monitoring visit reports
Document agreements and discussions on trial administration in relevant communications
Obtain signed informed consent forms from each subject prior to trial participation
Document all changes/additions or corrections made to CRF after initial data recording
Originating investigator must notify sponsor of serious adverse events
Sponsor and/or investigator must notify regulatory authorities of unexpected serious adverse drug reactions
Sponsor and/or investigator must notify IRBs/IECs of unexpected serious adverse drug reactions
Sponsor must notify investigators of safety information
Provide interim or annual reports to IRB/IEC
Maintain a subject screening log to document identification of pre-trial screening subjects
Investigator/institution must keep a confidential list of names of all subjects allocated to trial numbers
Investigator must document chronological enrolment of subjects by trial number
Investigator must document that investigational products have been used according to the protocol
Signatures and initials of all persons authorized to make CRF entries/corrections must be documented
Location and identification of retained body fluid/tissue samples must be documented
Final accounting of investigational products at the site must be documented after trial completion
Document destruction of unused investigational products by sponsor or at site
Maintain a confidential completed subject identification code list
Keep subject identification list for agreed upon time
Document that audit was performed via audit certificate if available
Prepare final trial close-out monitoring report
Return treatment allocation and decoding documentation to sponsor
Investigator must submit final report to IRB/IEC and regulatory authorities if required
Prepare clinical study report documenting trial results and interpretation
Subjects should be properly informed on the processing of their personal data
A correct-mark symbol indicates an element should be included for an age group
A circle symbol indicates an element is optional for an age group
Respect child's refusal or dissent, even if assent not legally required
Analyze reasons for child's objections to trial participation
Explain how the investigational product works and its side effects
Describe how the investigational product will be administered
Address pain, discomfort, and fear associated with trial procedures
Allow participants to withdraw consent for future use of biological samples
Comply with General Data Protection Regulation (679/2016) for biological samples
Comply with EU General Data Protection Regulation
A summary of results should be presented in terms understandable to participants
